lines.text: There was something familiar about that kick in the pants I took.
You must be awfully sensitive to be able to tell one from another.
One thing about being a crook. You can spot another crook at fifty paces.
The scum of the whole country is coming west by the wagon-load. We got more criminals than we have citizens.
Sounds like an up-and-coming country. Looks like we arrived just in time.
There ain't no permanence in this business. You just begin to like somebody and he turns up dead.
You can lose a lot of people you don't like that way, too.
I'd like to know why you blew up that tree. You might have killed somebody.
I figured it out. No tree, no hanging.

Lola, I've been working on something for two years. Something that will make me the biggest man in this part of the country. I'm within an inch of doing it now. You wouldn't want me to quit at this point.
The biggest man in the cemetery is still pretty small.
I've got an idea that's bigger than anything you've ever heard. It'll take time... and it'll take brains.
I got plenty of time.
Are we splitting up?
That's the general idea.
Why?
You're bad news, Lance. You're not interested enough in growing old.
You have to take chances in this line of work.
Not as many as I've been taking with you.
What about that $3000 we have buried at Sage Fork.
We split it.
How?
We can't all go together. The first one there takes his share and leaves the rest.
You must trust me a lot, Charlie.
I do. Besides, I 've got a faster horse.
This is your last chance to say anything.
You're hanging two innocent men!
Innocent? You were caught leaving town with the mayor's wife, riding stolen horses and carrying money from two bank holdups!
You call that evidence?
There's enough uncertainty about marriage without sitting home wondering what tree your husband is hanging from that night.
Wouldn't it be a little crowded on the honeymoon? You and me and the hanging party?
I'll leave them at home.
Mr. and Mrs. Black Bart. Somehow it doesn't sound too permanent.
You have to admit, it doesn't sound dull.
How did you know I was on that stage?
Very simple. There's posters of you from here to the Mexican border.
Is that why you chose to rob that particular stage? Because I was on it?
Well, the $10,000 they were carrying didn't keep me away, either.
I'll be generous about your faults if you'll be generous about mine.
Robbin' stagecoaches hardly comes under the heading of a minor vice.
Are you in trouble?
In Nevada and everywhere east of there I am. Here, I'm all right.
What are you two doing in town?
Getting out of Texas, mostly.
Something has been bothering me lately.
What's that?
We've been run out of Kansas, Nevada, Texas and New Mexico and Arizona. What do we do when we run out of places.
Move further west.
There's an ocean out there someplace.
We could start back in Kansas again. They must have a new sheriff by this time.
You don't seem to be nervous traveling alone.
Should I be?
This is dangerous country for a woman traveling alone.
I've never been in one that wasn't.
